'''Albert Collins''' (October 1, 1932 – November 24, 1993)<ref name="amg">[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p6321|pure_url=yes}} Albert Collins Biography by Richard Skeely]. Allmusic Website.</ref> was an American [[electric blues]] guitarist and singer with a distinctive guitar style. Collins was noted for his powerful playing and his use of altered tunings and capo. His long association with the Fender Telecaster led to the title "The Master of the Telecaster".<ref name="Music">{{cite book
| first= Paul
| last= Du Noyer
| year= 2003
| title= The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Music
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Flame Tree Publishing 
| location= Fulham, London
| isbn= 1-904041-96-5
| page= 164}}</ref>

==Early life==
Albert Collins was born in [[Leona, Texas]], on 1 October 1932.<ref>[http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fcowg John G. Johnson, "COLLINS, ALBERT," Handbook of Texas Online.] Accessed 17 July 2013. Published by the Texas State Historical Association.</ref> He was introduced to the guitar at an early age through his cousin [[Lightnin' Hopkins]], also a Leona resident, who frequently played at family associations (reunions). In 1938 his family relocated to [[Marquez, Texas]], eventually settling in [[Houston, Texas]], in 1941<ref name="BluesGuitar">''Blues Guitar (The Men Who Made The Music)'' - Guitar Player Magazine. Miller Freeman Books 1993 2nd Edition. ISBN 0-87930-292-5. p246 - p259 Albert Collins Interview.</ref> where he later attended [[Jack Yates High School]].<ref name="VitalBlues">''Albert Collins - Vital Blues Guitar Series''. Transcriptions: Richard DeVinck. Creative Concepts Publishing (California) 1994. ISBN 1-56922-047-6.</ref> Collins initially took piano lessons when he was young but during periods when his piano tutor was unavailable his cousin Willow Young would loan him his guitar and taught Collins the altered tuning that he used throughout his career.<ref name="BluesGuitar" /> At the age of twelve, he made the decision to concentrate on learning the guitar after hearing "Boogie Chillen'" by John Lee Hooker. At eighteen Collins started his own group called the Rhythm Rockers in which he honed his craft while remaining in employment including four years working on a ranch in Normangee, Texas, followed by twelve years of driving a truck for various companies.<ref name="BluesGuitar" /><ref name="VitalBlues" /> Collins initially played an Epiphone guitar during his first two years with the Rhythm Rockers but in 1952 after seeing [[Clarence "Gatemouth" Brown]] playing a Fender Esquire he decided to purchase a Fender. Collins had wanted to buy a Telecaster but due to their cost he opted instead to buy an Esquire which he then took to the Parker Music Company in Houston to have it fitted with a genuine Telecaster neck; this would remain his main guitar up until his move to California and the guitar that he used on his earliest recordings including his signature song "Frosty".<ref name="BluesGuitar" /> In 1954 Collins, then aged 22 and still without a record release, was joined in the Rhythm Rockers by the 17 year old [[Johnny Copeland]] who had just left the Dukes of Rhythm (a band he had started with Houston blues musician Joe "Guitar" Hughes).<ref name="Hudson2001">{{cite book|author=Kathleen Hudson|title=Telling Stories, Writing Songs: An Album of Texas Songwriters|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=2fRx28bO7cAC&pg=PA221|accessdate=18 July 2013|year=2001|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-78871-8|pages=221–}}</ref>

==Career==
Collins started to play regularly in Houston most notably at Shady's Playhouse where James "Widemouth" Brown (brother of Clarence "Gatemouth" Brown) and other well-known Houston blues musicians would meet for the ''Blue Monday'' jams.<ref>{{cite book|title=Down in Houston: Bayou City Blues|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=gdY5aJMVKkcC&pg=PA59|accessdate=16 June 2013|year=2003|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-79159-6|pages=59–}}</ref><ref>[http://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2003-05-30/161515/ Shady's Playhouse - Elgin & Ennis venue] Article: Come Go Home With Me (Tracing the Bayou City's Blues Legacy). Publication: The Austin Chronicle 30 May 2003. Retrieved 16 June 2013.</ref> By the mid 1950s he had established his reputation as a local guitarist of note and had started to appear regularly at a Fifth Ward club called Walter's Lounge with the group Big Tiny and the Thunderbirds.<ref name="Hudson2013">{{cite book|author=Kathleen Hudson|title=Women in Texas Music: Stories and Songs|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=t-c78muIZ8AC&pg=PA140|accessdate=19 July 2013|date=4 April 2013|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-75286-3|pages=140–}}</ref><ref name="DownInHouston02">{{cite book|title=Down in Houston: Bayou City Blues|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=gdY5aJMVKkcC&pg=PA100|accessdate=19 July 2013|date=1 April 2003|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-79159-6|pages=100–}}</ref> The saxophonist and music teacher Henry Hayes had heard about Collins from [[Joe "Guitar" Hughes]]. After seeing him perform live Hayes encouraged Collins to record a single for Kangaroo Records; a label he had started with his friend M. L. Young.<ref name="Govenar2008-2">{{cite book|author=Alan B. Govenar|title=Texas Blues: The Rise of a Contemporary Sound|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=68Re4trXKqoC&pg=PA223|accessdate=4 July 2013|date=9 October 2008|publisher=Texas A&M University Press|isbn=978-1-58544-605-6|pages=223–}}</ref> Collins recorded his debut single "The Freeze" b/w "Collins Shuffle" for Kangaroo Records at [[Gold_Star_Records#Bill_Quinn_and_Gold_Star_Studios|Gold Star Studios]], Houston, in the spring of 1958 with Henry Hayes on saxophone.<ref name="Bradley">{{cite book|author=Andy Bradley|title=House of Hits|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=XsvWyg1u0UwC&pg=PA83|accessdate=23 June 2013|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-78324-9|pages=83–}}</ref> Texas blues bands of this period incorporated a horn section and Collins later credited Henry Hayes with teaching him how to arrange for horns.<ref name="BluesGuitar" /> In 1964 he recorded "Frosty" at Gulf Coast Recording Studio, Beaumont, Texas, for Hall Records owned by Bill Hall, who had signed Collins on the recommendation of [[Jack Clement|Cowboy Jack Clement]]; a songwriter and producer who had engineered sessions for Jerry Lee Lewis and Johnny Cash at Sun Records.<ref>[http://www.cowboyjackclement.com/bio/interviews/lomax_part1.html Cowboy Jack Clement Interview c.1977] at Clement's Official Site. Retrieved 01 July 2013</ref> His debut album  ''The Cool Sounds Of Albert Collins'' was released in 1965 on the TCF label and consisted of previously released instrumentals including "Thaw Out" and "Don't Lose Your Cool".<ref name="Bradley02">{{cite book|author=Andy Bradley|title=House of Hits|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=XsvWyg1u0UwC&pg=PA129|accessdate=7 July 2013|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-78324-9|pages=129–}}</ref>

On 19 June 1968 the group [[Canned Heat]] were playing at the Music Hall in Houston and a friend of theirs mentioned that Collins was playing at the Ponderosa Club which they duly attended.<ref name="La2013">{{cite book|author=Adolfo De La|title=Living the Blues|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=QhK6p8Z_Ih8C&pg=PT78|accessdate=18 June 2013|date=21 February 2013|publisher=eBookIt.com|isbn=978-1-4566-0332-8|pages=78–}}</ref> After Collins had finished playing they introduced themselves and offered to help secure an agent for him as well as an introduction to [[Imperial Records]] in California.<ref>[http://www.cannedheatmusic.com/bio.htm Canned Heat Biography - Official Site] Authors: Skip Taylor and Brett Lemke Published: 2006. Retrieved 18 June 2013.</ref> With the offer of a record deal and regular live work Collins made the decision to move; relocating at first to Kansas City in July 1968, where he played in the organ trio of keyboardist Lawrence Wright, and then in November to Palo Alto, California.<ref name="BluesGuitar" /> Collins chose ''Love Can Be Found Anywhere (Even In A Guitar)'' from the lyrics of Canned Heat's "Fried Hockey Boogie" as the title for his 1968 Imperial album in honor of Canned Heat and their lead-singer Bob Hite who had also provided the liner notes for the album.<ref name="BluesGuitar" /> In the spring of 1969 he was hired by Bob Krasnow to play on the Ike and Tina Turner album ''The Hunter'' which was released on Krasnow's [[Blue Thumb Records|Blue Thumb]] label.<ref name="Danchin2001">{{cite book|author=Sebastian Danchin|title=Earl Hooker, Blues Master|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=-G76U3ikkFAC&pg=PA274|accessdate=21 July 2013|date=1 January 2001|publisher=Univ. Press of Mississippi|isbn=978-1-57806-307-9|pages=274–}}</ref><ref>[http://guitarinternational.com/2010/12/05/robert-cray-a-retrospective-interview/ Robert Cray Interview] at Guitar International. Interviewer: Rick Landers. Published: no date given. Retrieved 21 July 2013.</ref> The move to California was proving to be the right decision with Collins establishing himself as a regular act on the West Coast circuit playing at the Fillmore West and Whisky a Go Go<ref name="BluesGuitar" /> as well as the [[Newport Pop Festival|"Newport 69"]] festival in Northridge, California, in June 1969 and the Gold Rush Festival at Lake Amador, California, in October.<ref name="Hunter2012">{{cite book|author=Dave Hunter|title=The Fender Telecaster: The Life and Times of the Electric Guitar That Changed the World|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=7sFrOQv9I5kC&pg=PA105|accessdate=22 July 2013|date=15 October 2012|publisher=Voyageur Press|isbn=978-0-7603-4138-4|pages=105–}}</ref><ref name="PoultneyArchives2006">{{cite book|author1=John Poultney|author2=Amador County Archives|title=Amador County, (CA)|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=dNw8gUtLmocC&pg=PA44|accessdate=4 July 2013|date=November 2006|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|isbn=978-0-7385-4701-5|pages=44–}}</ref> In December 1970 his debut album ''The Cool Sounds Of Albert Collins'' was reissued as ''Truckin’ With Albert Collins'' by Blue Thumb Records.<ref name="Inc.1970">{{cite book|author=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|title=Billboard|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=oCkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA59|accessdate=17 July 2013|date=5 December 1970|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=59–|id={{ISSN|00062510}}}}</ref>

In November 1971 the Denver label Tumbleweed, which had been newly created by Larry Ray and [[Bill Szymczyk]], released the Collins album ''There's Gotta Be A Change''; it was the labels first official release.<ref name="Inc.1971a">{{cite book|author=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|title=Billboard|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=QA8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA53|accessdate=5 July 2013|date=27 November 1971|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=53–|id={{ISSN|00062510}}}}</ref><ref name="Inc.1971b">{{cite book|author=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|title=Billboard|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=iA8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA13|accessdate=5 July 2013|date=4 December 1971|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=13–|id={{ISSN|00062510}}}}</ref> The single "Get Your Business Straight" b/w "Frog Jumpin" was released by Tumbleweed in February 1972.<ref name="Inc.1972a">{{cite book|author=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|title=Billboard|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=8EQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA24|accessdate=5 July 2013|date=12 February 1972|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=24–|id={{ISSN|00062510}}}}</ref><ref name="Inc.1972b">{{cite book|author=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|title=Billboard|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=uSgEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA70|accessdate=5 July 2013|date=11 March 1972|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=70–|id={{ISSN|00062510}}}}</ref> In 1973 Tumbleweed closed due to financial problems leaving Collins without a record label.<ref name="Brown2004">{{cite book|author=G. Brown|title=Colorado Rocks!: A Half-Century of Music in Colorado|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=10eRzwLWOEwC&pg=PT9|accessdate=5 July 2013|year=2004|publisher=Pruett Publishing|isbn=978-0-87108-930-4|pages=9–}}</ref> He was signed by [[Bruce Iglauer]], owner of [[Alligator Records]], in 1978 on the recommendation of Dick Shurman whom Collins had met in Seattle.<ref name="VitalBlues" /> His first release for the label was ''Ice Pickin''' (1978) which was recorded at Curtom Studios, Chicago, and produced by Iglauer, Shurman and Richard McLeese. On 2 February 1978 Collins appeared in concert with the Dutch band Barrelhouse which was his first live appearance outside of the United States. The concert was filmed for the Dutch TV show ''Tros Sesjun'' and was subsequently released on vinyl in 1979 by Munich Records as ''Albert Collins & Barrelhouse Live''.<ref>[http://www.barrelhouse.nl/bio/en.swf Albert Collins Details at Barrelhouse Info] No publication date. Retrieved 26 June 2013.</ref> Collins won a [[Blues Music Award|W. C. Handy Award]] in the category Best Contemporary Blues Album in 1983 for his Alligator release ''Don't Lose Your Cool''.<ref>[https://www.blues.org/bluesmusicawards/pastyears.php4.php#ref=bluesmusicawards_pastyears Blues Music Award - Past Winners] at The Blues Foundation. Retrieved 21 July 2013.</ref>

On 13 July 1985 Collins performed with [[George Thorogood|George Thorogood and the Destroyers]] at ''[[Live Aid]]'' appearing as guest soloist on "Madison Blues"; the US part of the charity concert was held at the JFK Stadium in Philadelphia and together with the simultaneously broadcast concerts from other countries was viewed by over 1.5 billion people.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/music/thelive8event/liveaid/history.shtml Live Aid 1985: How it all happened] BBC Article. Retrieved 20 July 2013.</ref> In December 1986 Collins appeared in concert with [[Etta James]] and [[Joe Walsh]] at the Wiltern Theater, Los Angeles, which was subsequently released on video under the title ''[[Jazzvisions|Jazzvisions: Jump The Blues Away]]''.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1986-11-28/entertainment/ca-15892_1_jazzvisions-wiltern-concerts Jazzvisions Wiltern Concerts Article] at Los Angeles Times. Published 28 November 1986. Retrieved 20 July 2013.</ref><ref name="Clear1993">{{cite book|author=Rebecca D. Clear|title=Jazz on Film and Video in the Library of Congress|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=NpQVuUAc1y8C&pg=PA77|accessdate=20 July 2013|year=1993|publisher=DIANE Publishing|isbn=978-0-7881-1436-6|pages=77–}}</ref> The backing musicians for the concert were Rick Rosas (bass), [[Michael Huey]] (drums), Ed Sanford (Hammond B3), Kip Noble (piano) and Josh Sklar (guitar). In 1986 Collins won a [[Grammy Award for Best Traditional Blues Album|Grammy Award]] with [[Robert Cray]] and Johnny Copeland for their album ''Showdown!''.<ref name="Music"/> Collins had finished working on his seventh Alligator album ''Cold Snap'' by October 1986 which was released shortly afterwards to good reviews and received a Grammy nomination for Best Traditional Blues Recording of 1987.<ref name="Inc.1986">{{cite book|author=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|title=Billboard|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=qSQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PA69|accessdate=20 July 2013|date=25 October 1986|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=1–|id={{ISSN|00062510}}}}</ref><ref name="Inc.1986B">{{cite book|author=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|title=Billboard|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=2SQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA64|accessdate=20 July 2013|date=20 December 1986|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=64–|id={{ISSN|00062510}}}}</ref> Collins cited the album as personally important to him due to the involvement of organist Jimmy McGriff; an early musical idol whom Collins had played with in Kansas City, Missouri, in 1966.<ref name="BluesGuitar" /> On 12 February 1987 he appeared as a musical guest on the NBC talk show ''Late Night with David Letterman''.<ref>[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1987-01-29/features/8701080144_1_albert-collins-carpeting-clarence-gatemouth-brown Alligator Takes A Big Bite Of Grammy Blues - Chicago Tribune Article] Published 29 January 1987. Correspondent: Larry Kart. Retrieved 07 July 2013.</ref> Collins made a cameo appearance in the 1987 comedy film ''[[Adventures in Babysitting]]''.<ref name="russell"/> In 1987 the American composer [[John Zorn]] and Albert Collins collaborated on a suite entitled "Two-Lane Highway" which was subsequently released on the Zorn album ''[[Spillane (album)|Spillane]]''. On 22 April 1988 Collins appeared at the New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival in a group that consisted of B.B. King, Eric Clapton and Stevie Ray Vaughan; the group played on the Riverboat President as it journeyed along the Mississippi River in recognition of the musical heritage of New Orleans and artists such as Fate Marable, Louis Armstrong and Henry Red Allen who had entertained passengers on the fleet of riverboats owned by the Streckfus Brothers.<ref>[http://articles.philly.com/1988-04-22/news/26252847_1_fair-grounds-race-track-band-concerts-musical-gumbo In New Orleans, A Musical Gumbo] at Philly. Correspondent: Gene Seymour. Published 22 April 1988. Retrieved 16 July 2013</ref><ref>[http://www.rollingstone.com/music/pictures/b-b-king-is-friends-with-everybody-20120131/new-orleans-jazz-festival-0258316 New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival 22 April 1988] at Rolling Stone. Retrieved 16 July 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.guitarworld.com/focused-stevie-ray-vaughan-comes-clean-1988-guitar-world-interview?page=0,4 Stevie Ray Vaughan Interview] at Guitar World (September 1988 Issue). Published 20 September 2011 by Bill Milkowski. Retrieved 16 July 2013.</ref>

Collins was signed to Pointblank Records, a subsidiary of Virgin Records, in 1991.<ref name="Buckley2003">{{cite book|author=Peter Buckley|title=The Rough Guide to Rock|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=7ctjc6UWCm4C&pg=PT226|accessdate=21 July 2013|year=2003|publisher=Rough Guides|isbn=978-1-84353-105-0|pages=226–}}</ref> Bruce Iglauer of Alligator Records expressed his disappointment at the departure of Collins while acknowledging that he had signed Collins on a "record to record" basis.<ref name="Jr.2010">{{cite book|author=Lincoln T Beauchamp, Jr.|title=BluesSpeak: The Best of the Original Chicago Blues Annual|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=xmIbg3YjqnMC&pg=PA60|accessdate=21 July 2013|year=2010|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0-252-07692-3|pages=60–}}</ref> On 15 November 1991 Collins performed with Robert Cray, Steve Cropper and Dave Edmunds at the [[Guitar Legends, Seville 1991|Guitar Legends]] event in Seville; a series of five concerts to promote the upcoming [[Seville Expo '92]].<ref>[http://tonyhollingsworth.com/?q=content/guitar-legends Guitar Legends] at Tony Hollingsworth Official Site. Author Peter Elman. Published: not stated. Retrieved 17 July 2013.</ref> On 28 October 1991 Collins was filmed in concert for the music show ''Austin City Limits'' which was broadcast on 21 February 1992; the concert was released on DVD in April 2008 as ''Albert Collins Live From Austin, TX''.<ref>[http://acltv.com/anthology/ Austin City Limits - Albert Collins (Season 17 Episode 5 1992)] at Austin City Limits Official Site. Retrieved 17 July 2013.</ref> In 1993 Collins played at the Pointblank Borderline Blues Festival in London which ran from the 17 March to the 27 March; this would be his last appearance in the UK.<ref name="russell">{{cite book| first= Tony| last= Russell| year= 1997| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray| edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai| pages= 82–83| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> Collins was performing at the Paléo Festival in Nyon, Switzerland, in July 1993 when he was taken ill.<ref>[http://yeah.paleo.ch/en/edition/1993 Paléo Festival, Switzerland - Official Site] Retrieved 21 July 2013.</ref> He was diagnosed in mid August with [[lung cancer]] which had [[metastasized]] to his [[liver]], with an expected survival time of four months. Tracks from his last album ''Live '92/'93'' were recorded at shows that September. Albert Collins died on 24 November 1993 at the age of 61. He was interred at Davis Memorial Park, Las Vegas, Nevada.<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/1993/11/25/obituaries/albert-collins-guitarist-dies-influential-blues-stylist-was-61.html Albert Collins Notice - New York Times]. Correspondent Peter Watrous. Published 25 November 1993. Retrieved 16 June 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=7454 Albert Collins - Find A Grave Website]. Record added to site on 06 December 1999. Retrieved 15 June 2013.</ref> There was a posthumous nomination for his final album ''Live '92/'93'' at the 38th Grammy Awards of 1996 in the category of Best Blues Contemporary Album.<ref name="Inc.1996">{{cite book|author=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|title=Billboard|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zg4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA74|accessdate=29 June 2013|date=13 January 1996|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=74–|id={{ISSN|00062510}}}}</ref>

==Death and legacy==
After a three-month battle with cancer, Albert Collins died at his Las Vegas, Nevada home on November 24, 1993.  He was 61.  Surviving him were his wife, Gwendolyn, and his father, Andy Thomas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1993/11/25/obituaries/albert-collins-guitarist-dies-influential-blues-stylist-was-61.html|title=Albert Collins, Guitarist, Dies; Influential Blues Stylist Was 61|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2014-05-18}}</ref>

Albert Collins was an inspiration to a generation of Texas guitar players including Stevie Ray Vaughan and Jimmie Vaughan. He was amongst a small group of Texas blues players, along with Johnny "Guitar" Watson and Johnny Copeland, who together shaped the legacy of T-Bone Walker into a modern blues template that was to have a major influence on many later players. From an interview with Robert Cray in Guitar World magazine:

<blockquote>...it was seeing Albert Collins at a rock festival in 1969 that really turned his head around. Two years later, Collins played at Cray's high school graduation party in Tacoma, Washington, and the ice-pick sound really sunk in deep.

"That was it,” Cray recalls. "That changed my whole life around. From that moment I started seriously studying the blues."<ref>[http://www.guitarworld.com/robert-cray-discusses-albert-collins-gear-and-his-new-album-1989-guitar-world-interview?page=0,1 Robert Cray Interview at Guitar World] Published 30 September 2011. Guitar World January 1989. Retrieved 01 July 2013.</ref>
</blockquote>

Collins is remembered for his informal and audience-engaging live performances. He would frequently leave the stage whilst still playing to mingle with the audience.<ref>[http://www.bluesaudience.com/speakeasy.html The Blues Audience Newsletter Editorial] from the August/September 2007 issue. Publisher and Editor: Diana Shonk. Retrieved 03 July 2013.</ref> The use of an extended guitar lead allowed Collins to go outside of clubs to the sidewalk with one anecdote stating that he left a club with the audience in tow to visit the store next door to buy a candy bar without once stopping his act.<ref>[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1993-12-10/entertainment/9312100134_1_clarence-gatemouth-brown-blues-alligator-records Albert Collins Notice - Chicago Tribune] Published 10 December 1993. Correspondent: Bill Dahl. Retrieved 04 July 2013.</ref>

He is also remembered for his humorous stage presence which is recounted in the documentary ''Antones: Austin's Home of the Blues'': Collins was playing a lengthy solo one night at Antone's and left the building whilst still playing. Collins returned to the stage still playing the solo and resumed entertaining the audience in person. Shortly afterwards a man arrived at the club and gave Collins the pizza which he had just ordered.<ref>[http://www.thewittliffcollections.txstate.edu/research/a-z/antones.html Antone's Home of the Blues] at The Wittliff Collections, Texas State University. Retrieved 21 July 2013.</ref>
